unnormalised: Someone asked me about neurology, so I'll share my experience. My Nana, R.K. Sharma, started having these weird dizzy spells back in '22. Initially, we brushed it off as old age – he was 78, after all. Plus, he always insisted on his evening walks, rain or shine, so we thought maybe he was just overdoing it. Mom kept saying, "Papa, slow down! What's the hurry?" but he wouldn't listen. Then, one day in March '23, he collapsed at the dinner table. That's when we knew it was serious.
normalised: Someone asked me about neurology, so I will share my experience. My Nana, R-K Sharma, started having these weird dizzy spells back in two thousand and twenty two. Initially, we brushed it off as old age – he was seventy eight, after all. Plus, he always insisted on his evening walks, rain or shine, so we thought maybe he was just overdoing it. Mom kept saying, "Papa, slow down! What is the hurry?" but he would not listen. Then, one day in March two thousand and twenty three, he collapsed at the dinner table. That is when we knew it was serious.

unnormalised: We rushed him to AIIMS Delhi. The neurologist, Dr. Gupta, ran a bunch of tests - MRI, EEG, the works. Turns out, Nana had a small stroke. Doc Gupta explained it all to us, using big words like "cerebrovascular accident" and "ischemic penumbra," which frankly, went right over my head. He prescribed some meds - Aspirin 75mg daily, plus something for his BP, since it was hovering around 160/90. He also recommended physiotherapy.
normalised: We rushed him to A-I-I-M-S Delhi. The neurologist, Doctor Gupta, ran a bunch of tests - M-R-I, E-E-G, the works. Turns out, Nana had a small stroke. Doc Gupta explained it all to us, using big words like "cerebrovascular accident" and "ischemic penumbra," which frankly, went right over my head. He prescribed some meds - Aspirin seventy five milligram daily, plus something for his B-P, since it was hovering around one hundred and sixty divided by ninety. He also recommended physiotherapy.

unnormalised: It's been a year, and Nana's doing much better. He still has some weakness on his left side, but he's walking with a cane and can manage most things on his own. We're so grateful to Dr. Gupta and the team at AIIMS. He still takes his meds religiously, and we've even convinced him to skip the evening walks when it's pouring cats and dogs during the monsoon. Neurology is complex, but timely intervention can really make a difference.
